Phoebe: Communication Comes Natural
By ANDREW GREEN
"If you're really interested in
something," she says, "you communicate it naturally. It's contagious. I don't see how anyone
could not be interested in Art
History."
As an associate professor of
History of Art, Dr. Phoebe Stanton
has shared her enthusiasm for the
subject with many Hopkins students
over the last decade. Her lectures in
Shaffer 3 draw a consistent crowd of
students, many of them science
majors and pre-meds.
Sitting in her University Parkway
apartment, Dr. Stanton talked
about her own art collection.
"Some people look at art as an
investment. I don't. All of this may
be burned after I'm gone, but as long
as I'm here, I get a great deal of
pleasure out of it."
Her tastes, like her opinions, are
eclectic. A beautiful, huge, abstract
canvas, a plaster sculpture done by
her son-a student at Antioch, a
complex, dreamlike architect's
drawing, and an op-artish design are
among the artworks hanging on the
walls.
"I believe in a free-form, organic,
instinctive way of life." She contrasted this with the lifestyles of
both the "establishment" and
today's youth.
She views youth as attempting to
escape from a convention-bound
society, only to entrap themselves

"They make terrible demands of

act.Speaking of the "generation gap
Dr. Stanton remarked, "The difference between my generation and
yours is that you can disappear into
a peer group, with similar con-

victions and dress."
She believes that this has already
played a major role in reshaping the
country. "In the last ten years more
change has taken place in American
life than took place in the rest of my
lifetime. Youth has had a lot to do
with it."
Curled in her chair, Dr. Stanton
often seemed strangely remote,
though her answers were clearly
honest and candid. Pausing infrequently, she expressed all her
opinions with conviction.
She has strong feelings on the
decay of America's cities, especially
Baltimore. Speaking earlier in the
day to a Levering Hall audience, she
mourned the erosion of Baltimore's
architectural character.
To prevent the demolition of what
remains of Baltimore's beauty, and
especially, to preserve the city's
salient architectural feature-the row
house-she called upon city dwellers
to raise their voices as taxpayers.
"There ought to be a kind of
Consumers Report on city planning. If people don't get assertive
about their tastes, our cities will be
nothing but sprawling developments
alongside highways."
"We have no gift for city living,"
she concluded, "unlike the
Europeans." Dr. Stanton visits
Europe often, both for her research
and for pleasure. She recently
returned from the Soviet Union.
"Moscow and Leningrad were

fascinating from the architectural
standpoint," she commented.
Dr. Stanton's original field was
19th Century diplomatic history. She
had almost completed her doctorate
when WW II broke out and she went
to work for the government.
After the war she switched fields
and went to London to study 19th
Century Architecture under the well
known art historian Nicolaus
Pevsner.
Returning to the U.S., she taught
at Bryn Mawr, then jointly at
Hopkins and Goucher before being
appointed to the Hopkins faculty in
1962.
Dr. Stanton grew up in Lebanon,
her father's native land. She still
makes occasional visits there, and
speaks warmly of the traditional
Arab hospitality.
"A deeper understanding of Arab
culture is essential if there's ever
going to be peace in the Middle
East," she said. "It's a pity no one
listened to the refugees until they
blew up 50 million dollars worth of
planes."
"I've been a pacifist all my life. I
don't believe that anything good can
be achieved through violence.'
As the interview was ending, Dr.
Stanton expressed surprise that she
hadn't been asked about Women's
Lib."I'm glad you didn't," she said.
"I think it's a very boring subject."
Perhaps Phoebe Stanton has been
there and gone.

The Barber Business: Razor-Thin Profits
In the quiet of the Levering
Hall
barbershop. Sam
Barranco is cutting hair.
Outside, the long-haired kids
are going down the steps to
the cafeteria, and for
Barranco, a barber for 47
Years, business has never
been so bad.
Barranco is putting the
finishing touches on one of his
rare customers, and you can
see that he feels he has
something in common with
Da Vinci.
Artistic Pride
He moves with a deft grace,
Patting the customer's hair
and then waltzing to his
counter to pick up a mirror.
He then glides back behind
the patron, moving from one
Side to the other, the mirror
held proudly, and the
customer eyes himself in the
Mirror and smiles.
Sam Barranco has won a
new friend.
Five years ago, Barranco
led three full-time barbers,
and twenty or thirty people a
slay would get haircuts.
Today, he only needs himself
and a part-time man to
handle the five daily
customers. He started his
Hopkins' shop in 1963.
Lots of Friends
At the end of the day,
Barranco sweeps up and talks
about his business. "This
Place doesn't make a profit,"
he says, leaning on the broom
handle, "but I love to be

here."
"I have another shop, so I
can afford to stay," he adds.
"I've made a lot of friends
here," Barranco comments,
and he recites a list that
sounds like the back of the
Hopkins catalog. "I used to
cut Dr. Eisenhower's hair,
and now I cut Dr. Gordon's
hair and Dean Strider's and
then there's Dr. Dierman and
Dr. Singleton and Mr.
Kauffman..."
And, he notes, "Outstanding Baltimoreans have
visited my other shop."
But still, like all barbers, he
is in trouble.
New Trend
"Long hair started in
England with the Beatles,"
Barranco remarks. "And
little by little, we saw
Americans start to change,"
he adds, moving his hands
expressively. "Consequently,
it wasn't too long before the
short haircut disappeared."
Barbers are now starting to
stress hairstyling and razorcuts in order to boost
business.
Transformation
Barranco has already
moved in this direction: The
barbershop is now called tne
Johns Hopkins Hair Styling
Salon. A Barranco razor-cut
costs $3.00 and a styling costs
$7.50.
"A good barber knows that
hair means something,"

Barranco says. "But hair
needs to be trimmed and
styled. I can make the longhaired young man into a
stylish young man."
Good Old Days
Still, the barbershop is not
the community center it used
to be. In the old days, when
men had crewcuts, you went
to the barbershop to read the
tabloids and hear the latest
gossip. The talkative barber

and

American folklore.
Although Barranco misses
the barber's clubhouse days,
he adds, with a sly grin, "We
have Playboy now instead of
the Police Gazette.'

ROTC Strengthens Security
The Hopkins ROTC unit is
tightening security measures
to keep rifles from being
stolen or distributed to
unauthorized persons.
Last week, the unit issued
special rifle ID cards to
supplement a tight security
program, begun several
years ago.
One cadet charged that the
new cards were distributed
because the military is
"paranoid."
A member of the ROTC
cadre added, "They fear
people will impersonate
cadets and be issued rifles."
Col. Eleazer Parmly,

ROTC program director,
however maintained, "I know
damn well we weren't
worried about someone
slipping in and taking a
rifle."
Left Wing Attacks
Parmly stated the cadet in
charge of supplies came up
with the idea of special ID
cards. "We also wanted the
ID cards to be uniform bet, ween Towson State, Community College of Baltimore
and Hopkins." Students from
Towson State and CCB are
allowed to join the Hopkins
ROTC unit.
Previously, cadets had to

surrender their University
cards when they were issued
rifles.
According to Parmly, 3
years ago, the Army began to
increase security to guard
against possible attack by left
wing groups. "The best way
to deter something diabolical
is through security." Parmly
noted.
The ROTC building, stated
Parmly, is now protected by
double locks and iron mesh on
the doors, as well as locks on
the rifle racks. The keys are
kept in a locked safe.
The unit also separates
firing pins from stored rifles.

Hopkins scientists are
critical of the Applied
Physics Laboratory, but they
defend the integrity of their
Navy-funded colleagues.
Many of these professors
hope for an end to classified

better
communication between APL and
Homewood and new APL
priorities. Yet they all
denounce the idea of controlling what is researched at
the lab.
Half of the projects at APL
are classified, and 82% of all
the research is military,
including work on missiles
and other weapons. The lab
was set up in 1942 by the Navy
in cooperation with Hopkins.
APL Potential
The Homewood scientists
are pleased by the nonmilitary work at APL, and
would like to see it expand.
"APL has potential to do
great service to the community," said Dr. George
Owen, Physics Department
chairman. "We should find
the most constructive avenue
of work for APL and push it."
He added,"We know there's a
lot there we can use."
Dean W. Robinson, a
Chemistry

asserted, "I think it's an evil
that the APL is engaged in the
type of classified research

it's balanced by the nonmilitary research going on."

be financially feasible,"
remarked Dr. V. David
Walker, Electrical
Engineering, "it would be
good for them to diversify."

Electrical Engineering, who
did non-military work at APL
this summer, commended the
lab's biomedical and transportation

Governance Trust
Does anyone trust anyone here?
The question was raised repeatedly at Friday's
General Faculty Assembly meeting, devoted exclusively to a discussion of the report of the summer
governance committee.
Trust is something the governance report does not
mention. Although the committee was not charged to
consider it, trust was the premise on which the panel
based its findings. It is the premise underlying all effective governmental systems. It is lacking at Hopkins.
But premises, though harder to construct than
arguments, can be built. The governance report does not
make an attempt. The charge of the committee
prohibited it.
The ASRC could be a step in the right direction but as
it is presently constituted it falls short. What the
governance committee is telling students, in effect, is:
Be satisfied with the ASRC, and let the faculty keep its
prerogatives. As long as the Academic Council exists in
tandem with the ASRC, the community's respect for the
ASRC's decision-making authority will suffer.
If the faculty is interested in cementing a base of
trust, it must take the first step (no one else can), invest
the Academic Council's authority in a body in which
student's have a say, and open up departmental
governance matters to students.

Honest Answer
It seems a shame that Hopkins is losing not only its
Education Department but its Master of Arts in
Teaching program. Faculty, students and administrators are unanimous in their favorable appraisal
of the program's worth. The problem, as Dean Benton
said, is money.
Those involved with the program have charged that
resources are available to maintain it on a reduced
level. They believe the program is being phased out
because it is too "non-academic" for Hopkins-- the same
argument given by members of the Social Relations
department in refusing to approve Dr. Wickwire's urban
involvement courses.
The charges need an honest answer.

Your October 2 editorial "APL's Present"
builds its unfair accusations on a mythical
foundation.
On various occasions last year, including
an open meeting in Shriver 'Hall and
numerous conversations with faculty and
student groups, I described all aspects of the

$60,000 annual administrative fee is a

creation of the APL Stabilization Fund in the
late 1950's, the limitations on its use, and the
fact that income from its investment is
allocated to the Division of Arts and
Sciences.

$250,000 per year, while not insignificant,
should not be the decisive factor in determining University policy on relations with
APL. I also described the arrangements
contained in the so-called Termination
Agreement.

stated to me by telephone that he had
likewise given full explanations on these
points in his discussions with student and
faculty groups.

understand the rather complex history and

conceal it.

Nothing would have been easier than to say
that the so-called intellectual and moral
arguments don't matter because we can't
afford to lose the money anyway.
In fact, the positions I took on both these
issues last spring are what I believe on the
intellectual and moral merits. The fact that
financial considerations may weigh on the
same side does not detract from those
merits.

"If you're really interested in
something," she says, "you communicate it naturally. It's contagious. I don't see how anyone

has shared her enthusiasm for the
subject with many Hopkins students

majors and pre-meds.
Sitting in her University Parkway
apartment, Dr. Stanton talked
about her own art collection.
"Some people look at art as an
investment. I don't. All of this may
be burned after I'm gone, but as long
as I'm here, I get a great deal of
pleasure out of it."
Her tastes, like her opinions, are
eclectic. A beautiful, huge, abstract
canvas, a plaster sculpture done by
her son-a student at Antioch, a
complex, dreamlike architect's
drawing, and an op-artish design are
among the artworks hanging on the
walls.
"I believe in a free-form, organic,
instinctive way of life." She contrasted this with the lifestyles of
both the "establishment" and
today's youth.
She views youth as attempting to
escape from a convention-bound
society, only to entrap themselves

Governance Trust
Does anyone trust anyone here?
The question was raised repeatedly at Friday's
General Faculty Assembly meeting, devoted exclusively to a discussion of the report of the summer
governance committee.
Trust is something the governance report does not
mention. Although the committee was not charged to
consider it, trust was the premise on which the panel
based its findings. It is the premise underlying all effective governmental systems. It is lacking at Hopkins.
But premises, though harder to construct than
arguments, can be built. The governance report does not
make an attempt. The charge of the committee
prohibited it.
The ASRC could be a step in the right direction but as
it is presently constituted it falls short. What the
governance committee is telling students, in effect, is:
Be satisfied with the ASRC, and let the faculty keep its
prerogatives. As long as the Academic Council exists in
tandem with the ASRC, the community's respect for the
ASRC's decision-making authority will suffer.
If the faculty is interested in cementing a base of
trust, it must take the first step (no one else can), invest
the Academic Council's authority in a body in which
student's have a say, and open up departmental
governance matters to students.

Honest Answer
It seems a shame that Hopkins is losing not only its
Education Department but its Master of Arts in
Teaching program. Faculty, students and administrators are unanimous in their favorable appraisal
of the program's worth. The problem, as Dean Benton
said, is money.
Those involved with the program have charged that
resources are available to maintain it on a reduced
level. They believe the program is being phased out
because it is too "non-academic" for Hopkins-- the same
argument given by members of the Social Relations
department in refusing to approve Dr. Wickwire's urban
involvement courses.
The charges need an honest answer.
